introduction.p: Here we will recap all of the facts we discussed in , as well as add in a fact from . We have already adequately discussed the ideas behind most of these facts, so for most of them we will not include a proof.

subsection.title: Effect of row operations on the determinant
subsection.p: We begin by recording a fact that helped us in our exploration of the effect of swapping rows on the determinant.

statement.p: Any row swap can be achieved by a sequence of an odd number of adjacent row swaps.

proof.title: Proof idea
proof.p: Suppose you want to swap rows R and R' in a matrix using only adjacent row swaps, where R appears higher in the matrix than R', and they are separated by m other rows. First move R down to the position just above R', then swap R and R' (which are now adjacent), then move R' up to the original position of R. Count the number of adjacent swaps that have been made as an expression in m, and notice that it is odd.

subsection.p: Here are all the things we learned in our activities in .

statement.p:
The following are true for every square matrix.
If there is a row of zeros, then the determinant is 0.
If two rows are swapped, then \det(\text{new matrix}) = -\det(\text{old matrix}).
If there are two identical rows, then the determinant is 0.
If a row is multiplied by constant k, then \det(\text{new matrix}) = k\det(\text{old matrix}).
If a whole matrix A is scalar multiplied by a constant k, then \det (kA) = k^n\det A, where n is the size of the matrix.
If there are two proportional rows, then the determinant is 0.
If a multiple of one row is added to another row, then \det(\text{new matrix}) = \det(\text{old matrix}).

subsection.p: And here are our connections between rows and columns with respect to the determinant.

statement.p: For every square matrix A, \det(\utrans{A}) = \det A.
The statements of remain true when every instance of the word row is replaced by the word column.

subsection.title: Determinants of elementary matrices
subsection.p: Finally, we'll record our discoveries about the determinants of elementary matrices.

ol.li: An elementary matrix corresponding to swapping rows has determinant -1.
An elementary matrix corresponding to multiplying a row by a constant k has determinant k.
An elementary matrix corresponding to adding a multiple of one row to another has determinant 1.
